Title:
The APSES Transcription Factor Vst1 is a Key Regulator of
Development in Verticillium Species
Keywords:
Verticillium, APSES proteins, melanized resting structure,
verticils
Abstract:
Plant pathogens of the genus Verticillium pose a threat to
many agronomically important crops worldwide. They are soilborne fungi
which lack host specificity and invade the plant systemically causing
wilt symptoms. In this work, we functionally characterized an APSES
family transcription factor, which we designated Vst1, in two
Verticillium species; V. dahliae, main causal agent of Verticillium wilt
which produces highly durable microsclerotia, and V. nonalfalfae, a
resting mycelium producing species. We showed that Vst1 is required for
microsclerotium biogenesis and plays a critical role in melanin
synthesis which is independent from its role in morphogenesis.
Generation of the characteristic verticillate conidiophore was also
fully dependent on Vst1 activity. Furthermore, sporulation rates in
liquid medium were greatly reduced in the mutants of both species. Yet
these strains were fully pathogenic in two different hosts. Comparison
of Vst1 functions and those of previously characterized components of
G-protein signaling suggest that both regulate conidiation and
microsclerotium biogenesis but playing opposite roles. We propose that
strains with altered Vst1 activity can be used in Verticillium species
as tools to analyze at the molecular level developmental processes which
play a role in the disease cycle and might therefore be a target for
disease control.
